citations.narrative:
In the outdoor runs of both Dog 1 and Dog 2, there is chicken wire along the gate that is rusted and broken with sharp
points that the dogs can access.
Sharp points can cause injury to the dogs. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they have no
sharp points or edges that could injure the dogs.
To be corrected by July 26th, 2022.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the outdoor area for the cats, there are thick weeds growing along the fence and around play structures.
Thick weeds and grasses can make it difficult to clean, manage pests, and maintain enclosures in good repair. The facility
must control weeds, grasses, and bushes to facilitate cleaning of the premises and pest control, and to protect the health
and well-being of the animals.
To be corrected by August 2, 2022.

In an enclosure housing three rabbits, there is a broken metal bracket on the wall. The edges of this broken bracket are
sharp and within reach of the rabbits in the enclosure.
Sharp points can cause injury to the animals. Primary enclosures for rabbits shall be structurally sound and maintained in
good repair to protect the rabbits from injury, to contain them, and to keep predators out.
To be corrected by July 26th, 2022.

In an enclosure housing the two pigs, “Sally” and “Ernie”, there is a post with nail heads sticking out of it. There are also
multiple screw tips pointing into the enclosure where the pigs can reach them.
In an enclosure housing the two pigs, “Delilah” and “Daphne”, there is a nail head protruding from the heated shelter in
the barn as well as two large screw heads protruding from the wall inside the barn. There are numerous wire ties with
sharp points in the outdoor area of the enclosure.
In the barn enclosure for the three sheep, there are three screw heads protruding from the wall next to the hay bin.
In the outdoor enclosure for the pig, “Martha”, there are multiple wire ties and wire fencing ends with sharp points.
In an enclosure housing six cows and four llamas, there are numerous wire ties that have sharp points sticking in where
the animals can reach them as well as two corral panels laying on the ground.
Sharp points and debris on the ground can cause injury to the animals. All enclosures shall be structurally sound and shall
be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

There is an accumulation of equipment, trash, and other items around the entrance to the barn and inside the barn
kitchen. The items outside the barn are collecting water and making it difficult to control weeds along the enclosure for
four pigs. The accumulation of trash, chemicals, and bins inside the barn kitchen makes it difficult to keep the area clean
which is attracting flies.
Accumulations of trash and other unnecessary items can negatively impact maintenance and cleaning of the facility and
contribute to pest issues. The premises shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury
and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be placed in
designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
To be corrected by August 2nd, 2022.

A large number of flies are inside the barn kitchen which is used to store and prepare food for the animals. These flies are
inside an open box of apples, inside the trash, and on feed that has been spilled on the ground.
There are numerous flies on the adult cows out in the pasture. The cows are repeatedly flicking their tails, swinging their
heads, and stamping their feet to remove flies.
Flies can contaminate food and cause discomfort to animals. A safe and effective program for the control of insects,
ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be established and maintained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
CINDY RHODES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:

In the outdoor area for the cats, there are thick weeds growing along the fence and around play structures.

3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
In an enclosure housing the two pigs, “Sally” and “Ernie”, there is a post with nail heads sticking out of it. There are also 
multiple screw tips pointing into the enclosure where the pigs can reach them. 
In an enclosure housing the two pigs, “Delilah” and “Daphne”, there is a nail head protruding from the heated shelter in

In the barn enclosure for the three sheep, there are three screw heads protruding from the wall next to the hay bin. 
In the outdoor enclosure for the pig, “Martha”, there are multiple wire ties and wire fencing ends with sharp points. 
In an enclosure housing six cows and four llamas, there are numerous wire ties that have sharp points sticking in where 
the animals can reach them as well as two corral panels laying on the ground. 
Sharp points and debris on the ground can cause injury to the animals. All enclosures shall be structurally sound and shall 
be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
There is an accumulation of equipment, trash, and other items around the entrance to the barn and inside the barn 
kitchen. The items outside the barn are collecting water and making it difficult to control weeds along the enclosure for

four pigs. The accumulation of trash, chemicals, and bins inside the barn kitchen makes it difficult to keep the area clean

Accumulations of trash and other unnecessary items can negatively impact maintenance and cleaning of the facility and

To be corrected by August 2nd, 2022. 
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
A large number of flies are inside the barn kitchen which is used to store and prepare food for the animals. These flies are 
inside an open box of apples, inside the trash, and on feed that has been spilled on the ground. 
There are numerous flies on the adult cows out in the pasture. The cows are repeatedly flicking their tails, swinging their 
heads, and stamping their feet to remove flies. 
Flies can contaminate food and cause discomfort to animals. A safe and effective program for the control of insects, 
ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be established and maintained. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CINDY RHODES, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
